instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
Hi,

Board = <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

I've been reading backlight sticky post and looking at potential failure using the two pics with all failure listed but I can't fix that one.
There's no backlight, I see apple logo and login window if I apply light to the lid.

<CHIP>U8300</CHIP> PIN1 = 5.14V
PIN 2 = 0V
PIN 4 = 5.14
PIN 6 = 0V
PIN 7 = 0V
PIN 8 = gnd

I've noticed that <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> is "open" when power is off and becomes 0.10 (Diode mode) (EDP_PANEL_ <SIGNAL>POWER_OR_PSR_EN</SIGNAL>) 3 seconds after I connect to magsafe. When I measure with "beep mode", the multimeter starts to "beep" after 3 seconds when I plug power.


<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> PIN 11 <SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> = 12.4V
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> PIN 12 <SIGNAL>ISNS_LCDBKLT_P</SIGNAL> = 12.5V
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> 18 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_A</SIGNAL> = 5.13V
<CHIP>U7700</CHIP> 17 <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 5.14V

<DIODE>D7710</DIODE> = 0
<TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR> 5 = 0 <SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_LCDBLT_SW</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R1430</RESISTOR> - <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V

Thanks
Sam

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
"When I measure with "beep mode", the multimeter starts to "beep" after 3 seconds when I plug power."
How many times we said on the forum NEVER ever check diode mode, or ohm scale with power applied???

Any history available?
Did you test with known good (2015) LCD assembly?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
the guy said he was in NY and screen stopped working suddenly.

I don't have another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> at the moment but I can look for one.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message: I've asked but so far I haven't find <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> to test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
You don't need fully working screen.
Broken screen, with confirmed working backlight is good enough for test; and something good to keep.
Try to get one from other service shop, or online auction.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
Hello

Took me a while but I finally found a cheap <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with working screen.

I've installed faulty motherboard and the problem is the same, so the issue in not the screen.

Any idea what i should look for ?

thanks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
I don't know where was my mind.
I just saw you have 3476 board, which isn't 2015 year.
So get 2012-14 screen for test.

I apologize for my mistake...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message: no problem but a working <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> should be ok?. I installed the fauly motherboard and it's the same problem, I see the icon if I apply light to the lid, so it's not the screen.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
So you can confirm, no backlight with known good compatible (2012-14) LCD assembly?

Do PRAM reset 2-3 times.
Check <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>-53 and their traces.
Post diode mode to ground readings at <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> (both) pins, w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
Thanks.
PRAM reset 2-3 times. - DONE, no change.

Check <RESISTOR>R7750</RESISTOR>-53 and their traces.
traces are working, resistor seems to be ok.


<DIODE>D7710</DIODE> without LCD
PIN 1 = 0.977
PIN 2 = 1.575

<DIODE>D7710</DIODE> with LCD
PIN1 = 0.969
PIN2 = 1.550

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No backlight - <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR> odd behaviour.
threads.message:
Check if you get any pulse to 30-40V in the first seconds at backlight output (when hear the chime).
Try changing <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
